text:
The **economy of Andorra** is a developed and free market economy driven by
finance, retail, and tourism. The country's gross domestic product (GDP) was
US$6.00 billion in 2024. Attractive for shoppers from France and Spain as a
free port, Andorra also has developed active summer and winter tourist
resorts. With some 270 hotels and 400 restaurants, as well as many shops, the
tourist trade employs a growing portion of the domestic labour force. An
estimated 10 million tourists visit annually.

There is a fairly active trade in consumer goods, including imported
manufactured items, which, because they are duty-free, are less expensive in
Andorra than in neighboring countries. Andorra's duty-free status also has had
a significant effect on the controversy concerning its relationship with the
European Union (EU). Its negotiations on duty-free status and relationship
with the EU began in 1987, soon after Spain joined. An agreement that went
into effect in July 1991 sets duty-free quotas and places limits on certain
items – mainly milk products, tobacco products and alcoholic beverages.
Andorra is permitted to maintain price differences from other EU countries,
and visitors enjoy limited duty-free allowances.

The results of Andorra's elections thus far indicate that many support the
government's reform initiatives and believe the country must, to some degree,
integrate into the European Union in order to continue to enjoy its
prosperity. Although arable land comprises less than 2% of the country,
agriculture was the mainstay of the Andorran economy until the upsurge in
tourism. Sheep raising has been the principal agricultural activity, but
tobacco growing is lucrative. Most of Andorra's food is imported.

In addition to handicrafts, manufacturing includes cigars, cigarettes and
furniture for domestic and export markets. A hydroelectric plant at Les
Escaldes, with a capacity of 26.5 megawatts, provides 40% of Andorra's
electricity; Spain provides the rest.

• In 2024, Andorra's gross domestic product (GDP) was approximately US$6.00 billion.
• The country is an attractive destination for shoppers from France and Spain, functioning as a free port that facilitates duty-free shopping.
• Andorra has developed extensive summer and winter tourist resorts, supporting its tourism industry.
• The country hosts around 270 hotels and 400 restaurants, along with numerous shops, indicating a robust tourist infrastructure.
• Tourism employs a growing segment of the domestic labor force, with an estimated 10 million tourists visiting annually.
• There is an active trade in consumer goods, including imported manufactured items, which are less expensive due to duty-free status, making them more affordable than in neighboring countries.
• Andorra's duty-free status has significantly influenced its relationship with the European Union (EU), sparking controversy and negotiations.
• Negotiations regarding duty-free status and the broader relationship with the EU began in 1987, shortly after Spain joined the EU.
• An agreement effective from July 1991 established duty-free quotas and imposed limits on certain items, notably milk products, tobacco, and alcoholic beverages.
• Under this agreement, Andorra is allowed to maintain price differences from other EU countries, and visitors are granted limited duty-free allowances.
• Electoral results in Andorra suggest that many citizens support government reform initiatives and believe that some degree of EU integration is necessary to sustain economic prosperity.
• Arable land accounts for less than 2% of Andorra's territory; historically, agriculture was the mainstay of the economy until tourism surged.
• Sheep raising has been the principal agricultural activity, while tobacco cultivation is considered lucrative.
• Most of Andorra's food supplies are imported, reflecting limited domestic agricultural production.
• The country’s manufacturing sector includes the production of cigars, cigarettes, and furniture, serving both domestic consumption and export markets.

generated_detailed_content: The economy of Andorra is classified as a developed, free market economy with its primary drivers rooted in the finance, retail, and tourism sectors. These industries have progressively shaped the economic landscape of the country, fostering growth and diversification beyond its traditionally agrarian roots. As of 2024, Andorra's gross domestic product (GDP) was estimated to be approximately US$6.00 billion, reflecting a relatively high per capita income and a stable economic environment supported by its strategic positioning and policy framework. Andorra's geographic location between France and Spain has played a significant role in its economic development, particularly through its status as a free port. This designation allows the country to operate as a duty-free shopping haven, attracting a substantial number of shoppers from its neighboring countries. The absence of import duties on many consumer goods makes Andorra an appealing destination for tourists and cross-border shoppers seeking lower prices on a variety of products, ranging from luxury items to everyday necessities. This duty-free status has not only boosted retail sales but has also contributed to the growth of the service sector, reinforcing Andorra's reputation as a commercial hub in the Pyrenees. Tourism forms a cornerstone of Andorra's economy, with the country investing heavily in the development of both summer and winter resorts. These resorts capitalize on the region's mountainous terrain and natural beauty, offering activities such as skiing, hiking, and mountain biking, which attract visitors year-round. The tourism infrastructure is well-developed, featuring approximately 270 hotels and 400 restaurants, alongside numerous retail establishments. This extensive network of accommodations and services supports the influx of tourists and contributes significantly to employment within the country. Tourism-related jobs have become a growing segment of the domestic labor force, with annual visitor numbers reaching an estimated 10 million. This influx of tourists not only sustains the hospitality sector but also stimulates ancillary industries, including transportation, entertainment, and local crafts. The trade environment in Andorra benefits from its duty-free status, which extends to a wide range of consumer goods, including imported manufactured items. These goods are generally less expensive than in neighboring France and Spain due to the absence of customs duties, making them more accessible to both residents and visitors. This price advantage has encouraged a vibrant market for consumer products, ranging from electronics and clothing to tobacco and alcohol. The affordability of these goods has reinforced Andorra's position as a shopping destination and has contributed to the overall economic vitality of the retail sector. However, Andorra's duty-free status has also been a source of complexity in its relationship with the European Union (EU). Since Spain's accession to the EU in 1986, Andorra has engaged in ongoing negotiations to reconcile its unique economic arrangements with the broader regulatory framework of the EU. These discussions, which began in 1987, have focused on establishing agreements that balance Andorra's economic interests with EU trade policies and customs regulations. A significant milestone in this process was the agreement that came into effect in July 1991, which introduced duty-free quotas and imposed limits on specific items, particularly milk products, tobacco, and alcoholic beverages. This accord aimed to regulate the flow of goods between Andorra and EU member states while preserving certain economic privileges for the microstate. Under the terms of the 1991 agreement, Andorra was permitted to maintain price differentials relative to other EU countries, allowing it to continue offering competitive pricing on various products. Additionally, visitors to Andorra were granted limited duty-free allowances, enabling them to bring back goods without incurring customs duties up to specified thresholds. These provisions sought to strike a balance between facilitating trade and preventing market distortions, reflecting the nuanced economic relationship between Andorra and the EU. The ongoing dialogue and adjustments to this framework underscore the importance of Andorra's duty-free status in shaping its external economic relations. Political developments within Andorra have also reflected the population’s attitudes toward economic reform and integration. Electoral outcomes suggest that a significant portion of the citizenry supports government initiatives aimed at reforming the economic and political structures of the country. Many Andorrans recognize that some degree of integration with the European Union is necessary to sustain and enhance economic prosperity, particularly in light of the challenges posed by globalization and regional economic dynamics. This sentiment has influenced policy discussions and negotiations, highlighting the interplay between domestic political will and international economic considerations. Agriculture historically formed the backbone of Andorra's economy, although its significance has diminished markedly in recent decades. The country's terrain limits arable land to less than 2% of its total territory, constraining the scope of agricultural activities. Within this limited agricultural sector, sheep raising has traditionally been the principal activity, providing wool, meat, and dairy products for local consumption. Tobacco cultivation has also been considered a lucrative enterprise, contributing to the rural economy and complementing other agricultural pursuits. Despite these activities, the majority of Andorra's food supplies are imported due to the limited capacity for domestic production, reflecting the country's reliance on external sources for sustenance. The manufacturing sector in Andorra remains relatively small but specialized, focusing on the production of goods such as cigars, cigarettes, and furniture. These products serve both the domestic market and export demands, contributing modestly to the country's industrial output. The manufacturing activities are often linked to traditional crafts and local expertise, maintaining cultural heritage while supporting economic diversification. This sector complements the dominant service-based economy by providing employment opportunities and generating additional revenue streams. Energy production in Andorra includes a hydroelectric plant located at Les Escaldes, which has a capacity of 26.5 megawatts. This facility supplies approximately 40% of the country's electricity needs, harnessing the region's hydrological resources to generate renewable energy. The remaining 60% of electricity consumption is met through imports from Spain, reflecting Andorra's interconnectedness with its neighbors in terms of energy infrastructure. The combination of domestic renewable energy production and imported electricity ensures a stable and reliable power supply for the country's residential, commercial, and industrial sectors. This energy arrangement underscores the balance between self-sufficiency and regional cooperation that characterizes many aspects of Andorra's economy.

Tourism is the mainstay of Andorra's economy, accounting for roughly 80% of
GDP. An estimated 9 million tourists visit annually, attracted by Andorra's
duty-free status and by its summer and winter resorts. Andorra's comparative
advantage has recently eroded as the economies of neighboring France and Spain
have been opened up, providing broader availability of goods and lower
tariffs. The banking sector, with its "tax haven" status, also contributes
substantially to the economy. Agricultural production is limited by a scarcity
of arable land, and most food has to be imported. The principal livestock
activity is sheep raising. Manufacturing consists mainly of cigarettes, cigars
and furniture. Andorra is a member of the EU Customs Union and is treated as
an EU member for trade in manufactured goods (no tariffs).
openai_summarised_points: • Tourism is the primary sector of Andorra's economy, accounting for approximately 80% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Annually, an estimated 9 million tourists visit Andorra, attracted by its duty-free status and its summer and winter resort facilities.

• The country's comparative economic advantage has diminished recently due to the opening of neighboring France and Spain's economies, which has increased the availability of goods and reduced tariffs.
• The banking sector in Andorra is significant to the economy, benefiting from the country's "tax haven" status, which attracts financial activities and services.
• Agricultural production in Andorra is limited primarily due to a scarcity of arable land, necessitating the importation of most food supplies.
• The main livestock activity in Andorra is sheep raising.
• Manufacturing industries in Andorra mainly produce cigarettes, cigars, and furniture.
• Andorra is a member of the European Union (EU) Customs Union and is treated as an EU member for trade purposes concerning manufactured goods, allowing it to trade without tariffs.
generated_detailed_content: Tourism has long been the cornerstone of Andorra's economy, constituting approximately 80% of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP). This overwhelming reliance on tourism stems from the principality’s unique geographic and economic attributes, which have positioned it as a favored destination for millions of visitors annually. Each year, an estimated 9 million tourists travel to Andorra, drawn by its distinctive duty-free status that offers a wide array of goods at competitive prices. This fiscal advantage is complemented by the country's well-developed resort facilities that cater to both summer and winter activities. In the winter months, Andorra's mountainous terrain and reliable snowfall create ideal conditions for skiing and snowboarding, attracting winter sports enthusiasts from across Europe and beyond. During the summer, the same alpine environment provides opportunities for hiking, mountain biking, and nature tourism, ensuring a steady influx of visitors throughout the year. Historically, Andorra’s economic model capitalized on its position as a tax haven and a duty-free zone, which allowed it to flourish as a shopping destination. However, in recent years, the country’s comparative economic advantage has diminished somewhat. This shift is largely due to the economic liberalization and integration of its neighboring countries, France and Spain. Both countries have progressively opened their markets, increasing the availability of goods and reducing tariffs, which has eroded the price differential that once made Andorra’s duty-free shopping particularly attractive. As a result, while tourism remains a vital sector, the principality has faced challenges in maintaining its previous level of competitive advantage in retail and related services. Alongside tourism, the banking sector plays a significant role in Andorra's economy. The country’s reputation as a "tax haven" has attracted a variety of financial activities and services, contributing substantially to economic output. Andorra’s banking institutions have historically benefited from favorable tax policies, banking secrecy, and regulatory frameworks that appeal to international clients seeking asset protection and tax optimization. This has made the financial sector a key pillar of the economy, providing employment and generating revenue through banking services, asset management, and related financial operations. However, in recent years, Andorra has taken steps to align its financial regulations with international standards, including increased transparency and cooperation with global tax authorities, which has gradually transformed the nature of its banking industry. Agricultural production in Andorra remains limited, primarily due to the scarcity of arable land within the principality’s mountainous terrain. The rugged topography and limited flat areas suitable for farming restrict the scale and diversity of agricultural activities. Consequently, Andorra imports the majority of its food supplies to meet domestic demand. Despite these limitations, agriculture continues to hold cultural and economic significance, particularly in rural areas where traditional practices persist. The main livestock activity in the country is sheep raising, which has historically been an integral part of Andorran rural life. Sheep farming supports the production of wool and meat, and it contributes to the maintenance of the landscape and biodiversity through grazing. This pastoral tradition also underpins local culinary customs and artisanal products, linking agriculture to tourism and cultural heritage. Manufacturing industries in Andorra are relatively modest in scale but contribute to the diversification of the economy beyond tourism and finance. The principal manufacturing outputs include cigarettes, cigars, and furniture. The production of tobacco products reflects both local demand and export opportunities, leveraging Andorra’s tax advantages to compete in regional markets. Furniture manufacturing, while limited, caters to domestic needs and niche markets, often emphasizing craftsmanship and quality. These industries provide employment opportunities and help to sustain economic activity in sectors less dependent on external factors such as tourism fluctuations or international finance. In terms of trade policy, Andorra is a member of the European Union (EU) Customs Union, which plays a crucial role in facilitating its economic interactions with neighboring countries and the broader European market. Although Andorra is not an EU member state, it is treated as such for trade purposes concerning manufactured goods. This arrangement allows Andorra to trade manufactured products with EU countries without the imposition of tariffs, simplifying cross-border commerce and enhancing the principality’s integration into the European economic area. The customs union membership supports Andorra’s export activities and provides consumers and businesses with access to a wide range of goods at competitive prices. It also necessitates compliance with certain EU regulations and standards, which helps maintain the quality and safety of products circulating within this trade framework. This special status reflects Andorra’s strategic approach to balancing its sovereignty with the economic benefits of closer ties to the European Union.

This high per capita income level reflects the country’s relatively small population combined with a prosperous economy. Similarly, information on household income or consumption shares for the lowest and highest 10% of the population was not accessible, limiting insights into income inequality or economic disparity. Such deflation can reflect subdued demand or other economic factors influencing price stability. The labor force in Andorra numbered 42,230 individuals in 2007, placing the country 185th globally in terms of labor pool size. Employment distribution by occupation during the same year showed that agriculture employed only about 0.3% of the workforce, underscoring the limited role of farming as a source of employment. Industry accounted for approximately 20.8% of employment, while the services sector dominated with 79% of the workforce engaged in various service-related occupations. The unemployment rate was relatively low at 3.7%, ranking Andorra 183rd worldwide, which suggests a generally healthy labor market with limited joblessness. Fiscal data from 2016 indicated that the government’s budget revenues amounted to US$1.872 billion, while expenditures were higher at US$2.06 billion, resulting in a budget deficit. This fiscal imbalance reflected the government’s spending priorities and revenue collection during that year. Andorra’s major industries included tourism, with skiing being a particularly significant attraction due to the country’s mountainous terrain and winter sports infrastructure. Banking also played a crucial role in the economy, benefiting from Andorra’s status as a financial center. Additionally, timber and furniture manufacturing constituted important industrial activities, contributing to both domestic consumption and export earnings. The industrial production growth rate experienced a decline of -3.9% in 2020, ranking Andorra 184th worldwide. This contraction in industrial output likely reflected the broader economic disruptions caused by global events during that year. These agricultural activities, though limited in scale, contributed to local food supply and rural livelihoods. with 1,157 and 1,144 companies respectively.
